Issues.Title: inputs that have a reference variable don't cause change detection
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug? Don't known / other ### Is this a regression? Yes ### Description If you have an input (say a checkbox): `` and then you use that checkbox reference variable in a conditional: `
Hello, World
` then checking the checkbox (keyboard or mouse) does not cause any change detection so the binding to the div visibility never updates. Adding any `onClick` (even something that doesn't bind to anything like `onClick="null"` causes change detection to happen and the value binds to the conditional. ### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug _No response_ ### Please provide the exception or error you saw _No response_ ### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`) ```true Angular CLI: 16.1.4 Node: 18.16.1 Package Manager: npm 9.5.1 OS: darwin arm64 Angular: 16.1.5 ... animations, cdk, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms ... platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic, router ``` ### Anything else? _No response_

Issues.Title: Nested computed signals have glitchy behavior due to garbage collection of WeakRef dependencies
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

core

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

There are many reasons you may end up with nested `computed()` signals, which could be deliberate or unintentionally. In the simplest form I'm talking about this, where a `computed` is created inside a computation and the value is accessed. Importantly, notice that `outerComputed` doesn't directly have a dependency on `counter`.

    const outerComputed = computed(() =>
    {
        const innerComputed = computed(() =>
        {
            return counter() % 5 == 0;
        });

        return innerComputed();
    });

Developers are most likely to encounter this without realizing if using something like [`selectSignal`](https://github.com/ngrx/platform/blob/47ef048213635c5395591d350189a932e7503d75/modules/component-store/src/component-store.ts#L328) from ngrx:

    const currentUserLastName = computed(() => store.selectSignal(s => s.users.filter(id => id == currentUserId()) )().lastName )

In the course of converting complex RxJS code (with nested `combineLatest` and `switchMap`) I have deliberately and unintentionally ended up with quite a lot of both of these in my codebase.

While they should probably generally be discouraged, an explicit 'inner computed' like the one above has the extremely useful characteristic that it can reduce unnecessary churn of the 'outer computed'. Of course that's the beauty of signals and is exactly the same as if  `innerComputed` was declared outside - but that may not always be possible.

In my example above `innerComputed` produces a `true` value every fifth time `counter` is incremented (then goes back to `false`). Since `innerComputed` is a direct dependency of `outerComputed` it is tracked internally via `producerAccessed()`. So when it changes, `outerComputed` will re-execute its computation (and yes that does recreate the innerComputed).

The problem I've come across is that since nothing ever saves a 'strong ref' to `innerComputed` it gets garbage collected sometime after the computation for `outerComputed` is run. That breaks the graph dependency from `outerComputed` which then stops working (at the whim of the garbage collector!)

Consequences / Observations: 
- If `outerComputed` had directly accessed `counter()` you would never notice a problem.
- If `innerComputed` was returned by `outerComputed` you would never notice a problem.
- If `outerComputed` has other dependencies, anytime one of those changes it will recreate and re-execute `innerComputed` so you perhaps would not notice a problem. This may be the hardest situation to debug!
- Overall this can lead to some incredibly glitchy behavior!

### Example
The Stackblitz example is a more comprehensive example of the above, with the addition of a second signal `animal()` that is a direct dependency of `outerComputed`. That can be used to trigger `outerComputed` to re-run its calculation (and recreate `innerComputed`) if it becomes broken. 

Here is a log of running this example:

- **Important:** Sometimes the garbage collector is much more aggressive than other times and it may take several attempts to observe this behavior.
- I am using Chrome on Windows 11. The garbage collector may behave differently elsewhere.
- Click 'Increment counter' 8 times and you should see something like the following:

> 14:36:22.299 main.ts:32 EFFECT: counter=0
> 14:36:22.299 main.ts:37 EFFECT: animal=cat
> 14:36:22.299 main.ts:49 executing computation. iteration 0
> 14:36:22.300 main.ts:61 EFFECT: outerComputed= {result: 'animal=cat, visible=true'}
> 14:36:23.380 main.ts:32 EFFECT: counter=1
> 14:36:23.380 main.ts:49 executing computation. iteration 1
> 14:36:23.380 main.ts:61 EFFECT: outerComputed= {result: 'animal=cat, visible=false'}
> 14:36:23.584 main.ts:32 EFFECT: counter=2
> 14:36:23.871 main.ts:32 EFFECT: counter=3
> 14:36:24.074 main.ts:32 EFFECT: counter=4
> 14:36:24.280 main.ts:32 EFFECT: counter=5
> 14:36:24.280 main.ts:49 executing computation. iteration 2
> 14:36:24.280 main.ts:61 EFFECT: outerComputed= {result: 'animal=cat, visible=true'}
> 14:36:24.504 main.ts:32 EFFECT: counter=6
> 14:36:24.504 main.ts:49 executing computation. iteration 3
> 14:36:24.504 main.ts:61 EFFECT: outerComputed= {result: 'animal=cat, visible=false'}
> 14:36:24.729 main.ts:32 EFFECT: counter=7
> 14:36:24.955 main.ts:32 EFFECT: counter=8

You can see the `effect` that logs `outerComputed()` was run only four times while `counter()` was incremented eight times.

Now wait a few seconds. The `innerComputed` is garbage collected (sometimes this takes longer of course). If you continue incrementing the counter neither `innerComputed` nor `outerComputed` will run anymore.

> 14:36:32.526 main.ts:32 EFFECT: counter=9
> 14:36:33.241 main.ts:32 EFFECT: counter=10
> 14:36:35.574 main.ts:32 EFFECT: counter=11
> 14:36:36.001 main.ts:32 EFFECT: counter=12
> 14:36:36.390 main.ts:32 EFFECT: counter=13
> 14:36:36.821 main.ts:32 EFFECT: counter=14
> 14:36:37.209 main.ts:32 EFFECT: counter=15

You can then toggle `animal` to restart things again.

### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

https://stackblitz.com/edit/nested-computed-1

### Please provide the exception or error you saw

_No response_

### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`)

```true
Angular CLI: 16.0.6
Node: 18.14.0
Package Manager: npm 9.3.1
OS: win32 x64

Angular: 16.1.5
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic, router
```


### Anything else?

I really really don't want to lose the ability to create a `computed` inside another `computed`. For an inner calculation whose value rarely changes, it's a really nice way to reduce the burden on the primary computed and associated template. I have some cases where it works perfectly for what I need.

I also think if APIs are returning computed Signals it's going to be pretty much impossible to disallow it. 

I don't know enough about how the signals graphs works to know if it's even possible to get a good fix for (maybe a computed needs to keep stronger references to dependencies if it detects creation of inner computeds?).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Nested computed signals have glitchy behavior due to garbage collection of WeakRef dependencies" (#51055)

Issues.Title: Revising the "@angular/platform-webworker" and "@angular/platform-webworker-dynamic" packages deprecation
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

_No response_

### Description

**Hello awesome developers!**

For start you will have to excuse my imprecise english. I was just reading about @angular/platform-webworker deprecated package and it's possiblities. It was an really awesome feature and developers were really happy about it. Why did Angular team decide to deprecate it?

Bootstraping Angular app in web worker could really improve mobile app development experience for developers who use for example: Ionic framework with Angular and Capacitor to bring their code to iOs and Android devices. Implementing some heavy computation code can be really challenging if you have complex logic and interface. Of course, you can use Web Workers and controll change detection with NgZone, but sometimes this is not enough so animations become janky, slow and it ruins UX on slower devices.

In my experience Angular is fast and extremely reliable, but I humbly think it can do better on mobile. Revitalizing those packages or adding simmilar feature would be awesome.

### Proposed solution

Revitalizing @angular/platform-webworker and @angular/platform-webworker-dynamic packages or creating different solution.

### Alternatives considered

Currently not.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Revising the "@angular/platform-webworker" and "@angular/platform-webworker-dynamic" packages deprecation" (#51053)

Issues.Title: refactor: standardize doctype declaration to <!DOCTYPE html>
Issues.Body:
## PR Checklist
Please check if your PR fulfills the following requirements:

- [x] The commit message follows our guidelines: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit
- [ ] Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features)
- [ ] Docs have been added / updated (for bug fixes / features)


## PR Type
What kind of change does this PR introduce?

<!-- Please check the one that applies to this PR using "x". -->

- [ ] Bugfix
- [ ] Feature
- [ ] Code style update (formatting, local variables)
- [x] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes)
- [ ] Build related changes
- [ ] CI related changes
- [ ] Documentation content changes
- [ ] angular.io application / infrastructure changes
- [ ] Other... Please describe:


## What is the current behavior?
<!-- Please describe the current behavior that you are modifying, or link to a relevant issue. -->

Issue Number: N/A

Currently, the Angular codebase contains different variations of the DOCTYPE declaration including `<!doctype html>`, `<!DOCTYPE html>` and `<!DOCTYPE HTML>`. Though these are all technically correct as the DOCTYPE is case-insensitive, they lead to inconsistency in the codebase.

## What is the new behavior?

This PR proposes to standardize the DOCTYPE declaration across the codebase to <!DOCTYPE html>, as recommended by the official HTML Living Standard documentation by WHATWG (https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/syntax.html#the-doctype). It helps to present the codebase in a more standardized and aligned way with the industry best practices.

## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No


<!-- If this PR contains a breaking change, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications below. -->


## Other information

Although this may seem like a minor detail, the standardization of these declarations adds to the overall quality and consistency of the project. This change was implemented using a find-and-replace command (cmd + R), so feel free to make any further changes, or alter the target merge branch if necessary.

I kindly request you to consider this PR for merging.

Thank you for your time and consideration.

Best Regards,
Mateusz

Issues.Title: refactor(core): decouple effects from change detection
Issues.Body:
Previously effects were queued as they became dirty, and this queue was flushed at various checkpoints during the change detection cycle. The result was that change detection _was_ the effect runner, and without executing CD, effects would not execute. This leads a particular tradeoff:

* effects are subject to unidirectional data flow (bad for dx)
* effects don't cause a new round of CD (good/bad depending on use case)
* effects can be used to implement control flow efficiently (desirable)

This commit changes the scheduling mechanism. Effects are now scheduled via the microtask queue. This changes the tradeoffs:

* effects are no longer limited by unidirectional data flow (easy dx)
* effects registered in the Angular zone will trigger CD after they run (same as `Promise.resolve` really)
* the public `effect()` type of effect probably isn't a good building block for our built-in control flow, and we'll need a new internal abstraction.

As `effect()` is in developer preview, changing the execution timing is not considered breaking even though it may impact current users.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "refactor(core): decouple effects from change detection" (#51049)

Issues.Title: build: update dependency build_bazel_rules_nodejs to v6
Issues.Body:
This PR contains the following updates:

| Package | Type | Update | Change |
|---|---|---|---|
| [build_bazel_rules_nodejs](https://togithub.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs) | http_archive | major | `5.8.3` -> `v6.0.0` |

---

### Release Notes

<details>
<summary>bazelbuild/rules_nodejs (build_bazel_rules_nodejs)</summary>

### [`v6.0.0`](https://togithub.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs/releases/tag/v6.0.0)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs/compare/5.8.3...v6.0.0)

#### Using Bzlmod with Bazel 6

1.  Enable with `common --enable_bzlmod` in `.bazelrc`.
2.  Add to your `MODULE.bazel` file:

```starlark
bazel_dep(name = "rules_nodejs", version = "6.0.0")
```

#### Using WORKSPACE

Paste this snippet into your  file:

```starlark
load("@​bazel_tools//tools/build_defs/repo:http.bzl", "http_archive")
http_archive(
    name = "rules_nodejs",
    sha256 = "a833b08fc846e27a73ac2b7062e4f48cace0e72a072c6c3fa756847dc44246dd",
    strip_prefix = "rules_nodejs-6.0.0",
    url = "https://github.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs/releases/download/v6.0.0/rules_nodejs-v6.0.0.tar.gz",
)
```

Issues.Title: Undocumented Feature of ng-template: direct access to context
Issues.Body:
### Describe the problem that you experienced

While creating a wrapper component for a vendor component that makes heavy use of ngTemplateOutlet, I needed a way to access the entire context object from an ng-template and pass it to ngTemplateOutlet. I could find no documentation on how to do this, but did find a couple github issues with this request (both closed and rejected).

https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/22323
https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/39884

I did, however, determine that there is an undocumented feature which allows you to access the entire context object and pass it through to the ngTemplateOutlet:

<ng-template pTemplate="body" *ngIf="bodyTemplate" let-ctx="valueOf()">
    <ng-container *ngTemplateOutlet="bodyTemplate; context: ctx"></ng-container>
</ng-template>

Since the code responsible for creation of these ng-template variables treats the value of the attribute as a property/method hanging off of the context, we can use the object's valueOf() function to retrieve the entire object.

### Enter the URL of the topic with the problem

https://angular.io/api/common/NgTemplateOutlet

### Describe what you were looking for in the documentation

I was hoping to find a way to reference the entire context object from an ng-template so that I can pass it through to the ngTemplateOutlet

### Describe the actions that led you to experience the problem

_No response_

### Describe what you want to experience that would fix the problem

Having this undocumented feature added to the documentation would help.

### Add a screenshot if that helps illustrate the problem

_No response_

_No response_

Issues.Title: fix(router): handle unhandled promise rejections with ErrorHandler
Issues.Body:
Pass errors from calls that returned promises to ErrorHandler. These calls returned promises that could fail but were neither caught nor propagated. This caused "Unhandled (in promise)" errors on the console.

**I'll be happy to add some unit test but I want to validate the approach first. Is it OK to inject ErrorHandlers in these two places?**

## PR Checklist
Please check if your PR fulfills the following requirements:

- [x] The commit message follows our guidelines: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit
- [ ] Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features)
- [ ] Docs have been added / updated (for bug fixes / features)


## PR Type
What kind of change does this PR introduce?

<!-- Please check the one that applies to this PR using "x". -->

- [x] Bugfix
- [ ] Feature
- [ ] Code style update (formatting, local variables)
- [ ] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes)
- [ ] Build related changes
- [ ] CI related changes
- [ ] Documentation content changes
- [ ] angular.io application / infrastructure changes
- [ ] Other... Please describe:


## What is the current behavior?
If a resolver rejects, "Unhandled (in promise)" errors are shown in the console (aside from the standard Angular navigation error handling). This is because there are calls to methods that return promises, but the results of these promises are never checked.

Issue Number: N/A


## What is the new behavior?
Promise rejections are caught and sent to ErrorHandler.handleError.

## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No

Issues.Title: fix(forms): handle controls with inherited property names
Issues.Body:
FormGroups now properly handle controls with names that are inherited from the 'controls' object prototype like 'constructor' and 'valueOf'.

Fixes #51029

Adding, removing, or setting a form control would sometimes error or return an inherited value for property names that are inherited from Object.prototype like `valueOf` and `constructor`.

## What is the new behavior?
Controls with names that match inherited properties are now treated the same as any other control, with no errors or surprising behavior.

Issues.Title: Usage of Lexer from "@angular/compiler" breaks in production build with v16
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

compiler

### Is this a regression?

Yes

### Description

After upgrading to angular v16 (16.1.3 more specifically) the production build of our app broke (at runtime).
The following error is thrown:

![Bildschirmfoto 2023-07-14 um 10 03 44](https://github.com/angular/angular/assets/26869118/0b46e98b-0ec3-4f9b-ade9-637018c84272)

The stack trace was pointing to an import from `@angular/compiler`, where we import the `Lexer` class from.
```
import { Lexer, Token } from '@angular/compiler';
```
I've removed that import temporarily in order to confirm it's the source of the issue and indeed the production build was starting up afterwards.

Note: It was working fine with v15.2.1 as well as when serving it on the dev-server with v16.1.3.

### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

_No response_

### Please provide the exception or error you saw

```true
Uncaught ReferenceError: md is not defined
```


### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`)

```true
Angular CLI: 16.1.3
Node: 16.17.1
Package Manager: npm 8.15.0
OS: darwin arm64

Angular: 16.1.3
... animations, cdk, cdk-experimental, cli, common, compiler
... compiler-cli, core, forms, language-service, material
... material-experimental, material-moment-adapter
... platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic, router

Package                          Version
----------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect        0.1601.3
@angular-devkit/build-angular    16.1.3
@angular-devkit/core             16.1.3
@angular-devkit/schematics       16.1.3
@angular-devkit/schematics-cli   16.1.3
@schematics/angular              16.1.3
ng-packagr                       16.1.0
rxjs                             7.8.1
typescript                       4.9.5
```


### Anything else?

Any suggestion how to make this work again?
Why is it working on the dev-server but not in production?

### Release Notes

<details>
<summary>bazelbuild/rules_nodejs (build_bazel_rules_nodejs)</summary>

### [`v6.0.0`](https://togithub.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs/releases/tag/v6.0.0)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs/compare/5.8.3...v6.0.0)

#### Using Bzlmod with Bazel 6

1.  Enable with `common --enable_bzlmod` in `.bazelrc`.
2.  Add to your `MODULE.bazel` file:

```starlark
bazel_dep(name = "rules_nodejs", version = "6.0.0")
```

#### Using WORKSPACE

Paste this snippet into your  file:

```starlark
load("@​bazel_tools//tools/build_defs/repo:http.bzl", "http_archive")
http_archive(
    name = "rules_nodejs",
    sha256 = "a833b08fc846e27a73ac2b7062e4f48cace0e72a072c6c3fa756847dc44246dd",
    strip_prefix = "rules_nodejs-6.0.0",
    url = "https://github.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs/releases/download/v6.0.0/rules_nodejs-v6.0.0.tar.gz",
)
```

#### What's Changed

-   Update NodeJS Versions by [@​mattem](https://togithub.com/mattem) in [https://github.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs/pull/3622](https://togithub.com/bazelbuild/rules_nodejs/pull/3622)

Issues.Title: perf(@angular-devkit/build-angular): inject Sass import/use directive importer information when resolving
Issues.Body: To correctly resolve a package based import reference in a Sass file with pnpm or Yarn PnP, the importer file path must be known. Unfortunately, the Sass compiler does not provided the importer file to import plugins. Previously to workaround this issue, all previously resolved stylesheets were tried as the importer path. This allowed the stylesheets to be resolved but it also could cause a potentially large increase in build time due to the amount of previous stylesheets that would need to be tried. To avoid the performance impact and to also provide more accurate information regarding the importer file, a lexer is now used to extract import information for a stylesheet and inject the importer file path into the specifier. This information is then extracted from the import specifier during the Sass resolution process and allows the underlying package resolution access to a viable location to resolve the package for all package managers. This information is currently limited to specifiers referencing the `@angular` and `@material` package scopes but a comprehensive pre-resolution process may be added in the future.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "perf(@angular-devkit/build-angular): inject Sass import/use directive importer information when resolving" (#25534)

### Release Notes

<details>
<summary>evanw/esbuild (esbuild)</summary>

### [`v0.18.13`](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/blob/HEAD/CHANGELOG.md#01813)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/compare/v0.18.12...v0.18.13)

-   Add the `--drop-labels=` option ([#​2398](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/issues/2398))

    If you want to conditionally disable some development-only code and have it not be present in the final production bundle, right now the most straightforward way of doing this is to use the `--define:` flag along with a specially-named global variable. For example, consider the following code:

    ```js
    function main() {
      DEV && doAnExpensiveCheck()
    }
    ```

    You can build this for development and production like this:

    -   Development: `esbuild --define:DEV=true`
    -   Production: `esbuild --define:DEV=false`

    One drawback of this approach is that the resulting code crashes if you don't provide a value for `DEV` with `--define:`. In practice this isn't that big of a problem, and there are also various ways to work around this.

    However, another approach that avoids this drawback is to use JavaScript label statements instead. That's what the `--drop-labels=` flag implements. For example, consider the following code:

    ```js
    function main() {
      DEV: doAnExpensiveCheck()
    }
    ```

    With this release, you can now build this for development and production like this:

    -   Development: `esbuild`
    -   Production: `esbuild --drop-labels=DEV`

    This means that code containing optional development-only checks can now be written such that it's safe to run without any additional configuration. The `--drop-labels=` flag takes comma-separated list of multiple label names to drop.

-   Avoid causing `unhandledRejection` during shutdown ([#​3219](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/issues/3219))

    All pending esbuild JavaScript API calls are supposed to fail if esbuild's underlying child process is unexpectedly terminated. This can happen if `SIGINT` is sent to the parent `node` process with Ctrl+C, for example. Previously doing this could also cause an unhandled promise rejection when esbuild attempted to communicate this failure to its own child process that no longer exists. This release now swallows this communication failure, which should prevent this internal unhandled promise rejection. This change means that you can now use esbuild's JavaScript API with a custom `SIGINT` handler that extends the lifetime of the `node` process without esbuild's internals causing an early exit due to an unhandled promise rejection.

-   Update browser compatibility table scripts

    The scripts that esbuild uses to compile its internal browser compatibility table have been overhauled. Briefly:

    -   Converted from JavaScript to TypeScript
    -   Fixed some bugs that resulted in small changes to the table
    -   Added [`caniuse-lite`](https://www.npmjs.com/package/caniuse-lite) and [`@mdn/browser-compat-data`](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@​mdn/browser-compat-data) as new data sources (replacing manually-copied information)

    This change means it's now much easier to keep esbuild's internal compatibility tables up to date. You can review the table changes here if you need to debug something about this change:

    -   [JS table changes](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/compare/d259b8fac717ee347c19bd8299f2c26d7c87481a...af1d35c372f78c14f364b63e819fd69548508f55#diff-1649eb68992c79753469f02c097de309adaf7231b45cc816c50bf751af400eb4)
    -   [CSS table changes](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/commit/95feb2e09877597cb929469ce43811bdf11f50c1#diff-4e1c4f269e02c5ea31cbd5138d66751e32cf0e240524ee8a966ac756f0e3c3cd)

</details>

Issues.Title: refactor(@angular-devkit/build-angular): configure AOT compiler to skip NgModule scope metadata emit in esbuild
Issues.Body: The esbuild plugin used within the esbuild-based browser application builder will now use the newly introduced internal `supportJitMode` AOT compiler option to disable the emit of NgModule scope metadata functions within the output code. This removes the need to perform an additional transformation of the AOT compiler generated code to immediately remove the metadata. The Angular CLI neither previously nor currently supports hybrid AOT/JIT mode. In the future if this support situation changes, additional behavior may be added control the internal `supportJitMode` option.

### Release Notes

<details>
<summary>evanw/esbuild (esbuild)</summary>

### [`v0.18.12`](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/blob/HEAD/CHANGELOG.md#01812)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/compare/v0.18.11...v0.18.12)

-   Fix a panic with `const enum` inside parentheses ([#​3205](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/issues/3205))

    This release fixes an edge case where esbuild could potentially panic if a TypeScript `const enum` statement was used inside of a parenthesized expression and was followed by certain other scope-related statements. Here's a minimal example that triggers this edge case:

    ```ts
    (() => {
      const enum E { a };
      () => E.a
    })
    ```

-   Allow a newline in the middle of TypeScript `export type` statement ([#​3225](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/issues/3225))

    Previously esbuild incorrectly rejected the following valid TypeScript code:

    ```ts
    export type
    { T };

    export type
    * as foo from 'bar';
    ```

    Code that uses a newline after `export type` is now allowed starting with this release.

-   Fix cross-module inlining of string enums ([#​3210](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/issues/3210))

    A refactoring typo in version 0.18.9 accidentally introduced a regression with cross-module inlining of string enums when combined with computed property accesses. This regression has been fixed.

-   Rewrite `.js` to `.ts` inside packages with `exports` ([#​3201](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/issues/3201))

    Packages with the `exports` field are supposed to disable node's path resolution behavior that allows you to import a file with a different extension than the one in the source code (for example, importing `foo/bar` to get `foo/bar.js`). And TypeScript has behavior where you can import a non-existent `.js` file and you will get the `.ts` file instead. Previously the presence of the `exports` field caused esbuild to disable all extension manipulation stuff which included both node's implicit file extension searching and TypeScript's file extension swapping. However, TypeScript appears to always apply file extension swapping even in this case. So with this release, esbuild will now rewrite `.js` to `.ts` even inside packages with `exports`.

-   Fix a redirect edge case in esbuild's development server ([#​3208](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/issues/3208))

    The development server canonicalizes directory URLs by adding a trailing slash. For example, visiting `/about` redirects to `/about/` if `/about/index.html` would be served. However, if the requested path begins with two slashes, then the redirect incorrectly turned into a protocol-relative URL. For example, visiting `//about` redirected to `//about/` which the browser turns into `http://about/`. This release fixes the bug by canonicalizing the URL path when doing this redirect.

</details>

<details>
<summary>postcss/postcss (postcss)</summary>

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/postcss/postcss/compare/8.4.25...8.4.26)

Issues.Title: Angular application will not run after upgrade to angular 16.
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

Don't known / other

### Is this a regression?

Yes

### Description

After upgrading my angular 14 application to angular 16, the application will not longer run after building. The application runs in development mode just fine so I did not think it would be a problem after building.  I first tried building and deploying the application via the build server and it will not run. Then I tried building manually from vscode terminal and deploying the app manually and still does not run. The main.js blows up with uncaught reference error where a variable (different variable name each build) is not defined. Of course the code is obfuscated so hard to see what it is trying to do at this point.   See uploaded images..

![Angular 16 error](https://github.com/angular/angular/assets/10948856/054d5796-7331-4626-8bea-4be68569e60c)
![Angular 16 error_2](https://github.com/angular/angular/assets/10948856/5756cb01-2d0c-4d30-9278-aa77a95001ce)


### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

https://test.tropicos.org

### Please provide the exception or error you saw

```true
the error is due to an undefined variable in the main.js generated file. here is the command used on the build server to build
node --max_old_space_size=8192 ./node_modules/@angular/cli/bin/ng build --aot=true --base-href="/" --configuration=production --output-path="$(Build.BinariesDirectory)\dist

for my manual test I used 
ng build --aot=true --base-href="/" --configuration="qa"
```


### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`)

```true
Angular CLI: 16.1.4
Node: 16.18.0
Package Manager: npm 8.19.2
OS: win32 x64

Angular: 16.1.4
... animations, cdk, cli, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core
... forms, language-service, localize, material
... platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic, router

Package                         Version
---------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect       0.1601.4
@angular-devkit/build-angular   16.1.4
@angular-devkit/core            16.1.4
@angular-devkit/schematics      16.1.4
@angular/flex-layout            15.0.0-beta.42
@schematics/angular             16.1.4
rxjs                            7.8.1
typescript                      5.1.6
```


### Anything else?

This is a very large project that was started in Angular 2 5 years ago and now is up to angular 14 (upgrading over the years) and trying to get to 16. It literally took 3 days of package upgrades to get to this point from 14 to 16 so I would like to try to figure out what is going on. I can provide more information and or files if needed but would like any help I can get to try to figure out why this is no longer working when built v.s. running in development server.

The application is served up in IIS on a Windows server. Nothing has changed and this is the first time having this problem. 
Thanks in advance for your help.

Issues.Title: semver@7.3.5 vulnerabilities in Angular 13.3.x
Issues.Body:
### Command

build

### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

13.3.x versions still use semver v7.3.5 which is vulnerable to [Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS)](https://security.snyk.io/vuln/SNYK-JS-SEMVER-3247795)
https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/30513671a2839714741eb7be5db24d3948841f12/packages/angular_devkit/build_angular/package.json#L59

Also, please upgrade core-js to >=3.23.3

Yarn didn't raise anything but npm does warn about this
```
npm WARN deprecated core-js@3.20.3:
core-js@<3.23.3 is no longer maintained and not recommended for usage due to the number of issues. Because of the V8 engine whims, feature detection in old core-js versions could cause a slowdown up to 100x even if nothing is polyfilled. Some versions have web compatibility issues.
```

### Minimal Reproduction

package.json

### Exception or Error

_No response_

### Your Environment

```text
Angular CLI: 14.2.1
Node: 14.20.0
Package Manager: yarn 1.22.17 
OS: linux x64
```

_No response_

Issues.Title: feat(@angular-devkit/build-angular): add support for serving SSR with dev-server when using the application builder
Issues.Body: This commit introduces experimental support for serving the application in SSR mode with the Vite based dev-server when using the application builder.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "feat(@angular-devkit/build-angular): add support for serving SSR with dev-server when using the application builder" (#25517)

Issues.Title: refactor(@angular-devkit/build-angular): ensure TS resolution cache with file replacements
Issues.Body: When overriding module resolution on a TypeScript Host object, TypeScript will not automatically create a resolution cache for the Host. Within the application build system the TypeScript resolution is only overrided if file replacements are used. A resolution cache is now manually created and added to the TypeScript Host when file replacements are present.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "refactor(@angular-devkit/build-angular): ensure TS resolution cache with file replacements" (#25520)

Issues.Title: perf(@angular-devkit/build-angular): only load browserslist in babel preset if needed
Issues.Body: The `browserslist` package is only needed in the custom Babel application preset if the `supportedBrowsers` option is specified. This option is not used within the esbuild-based browser application builder. The `browserslist` is now lazily imported only when needed and avoids the overhead of loading browser support data when not needed by the build.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "perf(@angular-devkit/build-angular): only load browserslist in babel preset if needed" (#25519)

Issues.Title: perf(@angular-devkit/build-angular): filter postcss usage based on content in esbuild builder
Issues.Body: When using the esbuild-based browser application builder, stylesheets that do not need any postcss processing will now skip the postcss step of the stylesheet build pipeline. Currently, only Tailwind CSS leverages postcss and Tailwind CSS is an opt-in feature. As a result, postcss will only be used if Tailwind CSS is configured for the project and a stylesheet contains one or more of the directives/functions specific to Tailwind as provided by https://tailwindcss.com/docs/functions-and-directives. This change should be most beneficial for component stylesheets which will rarely contain Tailwind specific rules that need additional processing.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "perf(@angular-devkit/build-angular): filter postcss usage based on content in esbuild builder" (#25518)

Issues.Title: fix(material/radio): clear selected radio button from group
Issues.Body:
In  #18081 the radio group was changed so that deselected buttons receive `tabindex="-1"` when there's a selected button. The problem is that we weren't clearing the reference to the selected button so it gets removed, the deselected buttons become unfocusable using the keyboard.

These changes clear the selected radio button on destroy.

Fixes #27461.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(material/radio): clear selected radio button from group" (#27466)

Issues.Title: bug(MatFormFieldModule): Resize not working when using in standalone
Issues.Body:
### Description

I spent lots of hours trying to find why I'm unable to resize my `mat-form-fields` and then found out that it is only not working beacuse we are using standalone components instead of NgModule.


### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:
I used the example from the official docs (v14, https://v14.material.angular.io/components/form-field/overview#form-field-theming) to reproduce this in Stackblitz:

1. This is a working example: https://stackblitz.com/edit/pghvre-upgcdz?file=package.json
2. This is the link with the same example, but as standalone component: https://stackblitz.com/edit/pghvre-sczu3y?file=src%2Fmain.ts


### Expected Behavior

No matter if I use `standalone: true` or an `NgModule` based setup the result should be the same. The padding that is applied to the form field should shrink like it does when using it with `NgModule`.


### Actual Behavior

In the standalone version, different classes are generated which don't render the correct resizing:
![image](https://github.com/angular/components/assets/2816893/29696e84-00f6-4a5a-9c11-3697d143d718)

For comparison, this is what the element looks like if `NgModule` is used:
![image](https://github.com/angular/components/assets/2816893/750c0e68-bced-4339-9459-cfecb414fbb2)

What I don't understand is why the "mdc" classes are applied on the one version and the "appereance" classes on the other one.

### Environment

- Angular: 16.1.4
- CDK/Material: 16.1.4
- Browser(s): Chrome and Firefox
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows 11

#### Edit
I updated the working Stackblitz to v16 as well.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "bug(MatFormFieldModule): Resize not working when using in standalone" (#27452)

Issues.Title: fix(material/chips): ensure that edit input query is re-evaluated on time
Issues.Body: Fixes an issue that showed up in an internal app where the edit input query wasn't being evaluated on time which led to a runtime error.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(material/chips): ensure that edit input query is re-evaluated on time" (#27465)

Issues.Title: fix(material/chips): wait for onStable when editing a chip
Issues.Body:
Address timing issue with MatChipRow. When a chip enters the editing state wait for ngZone's `onStable` event before accessing the ViewChild for the MatChipEditInput. Attempts to fix issue where editable chip goes blank when entering the editing state (#27462).

What seemed to be happening is that the view would render the MatChiEditInput when setting `_isEditing` to true, but sometimes the ViewChild would not be initialized in the component. Address this issue by adding additional wait using `_ngZone.onStable`.

Fix #27462.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(material/chips): wait for onStable when editing a chip" (#27464)

Issues.Title: bug(MatRadioGroup): paging options prevents keyboard focus
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

Using a `mat-paginator` to page the options in a `MatRadioGroup` prevents the radio group from receiving focus using the tab key on pages other than the first page.

### Reproduction

StackBlitz link: https://stackblitz.com/edit/q2wcmz

Steps to reproduce:
1. Click in the input box at the top to give it focus
2. Press tab; note that the radio group receives focus
3. Press tab again; note that this gives focus to the next-page button in the paginator
4. Press space or enter to change to the next page; note that the radio group options have changed
5. Press shift+tab; note that the paginator previous-page button receives focus
6. Press shift+tab again; note that the input box receives focus, skipping over the radio group
7. Press tab; note that the paginator receives focus, skipping over the radio group


### Expected Behavior

After changing pages, the radio group should still be able to receive focus using the keyboard.

### Actual Behavior

After changing pages, the radio group is unable to receive focus using the keyboard

### Environment

- Angular: 15.1.1
- CDK/Material: 15.1.1
- Browser(s): Chrome 114.0.5735.110, Firefox 115.0.2 (64-bit)
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows 10
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(MatRadioGroup): paging options prevents keyboard focus" (#27461)

Issues.Title: feat(theme): add the ability to add (even partial) background and foreground to color object

feat(theme): add the ability to add (even partial) background and foreground to color object

While declaring the primary, accent and warn via the color object is easy and straight-forward, the configuration of foreground and background proves rather tedious. This commit adds the ability to declare foreground and background in the color object when defining a theme, even partially, meaning that missing values are taken from the default light or dark theme respectively.

Fixes #11390, #6244

Issues.Title: bug(Clipboard): Copy to clipboard doesn't work in elem.requestFullscreen()
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

When using document.element.requestFullscreen(), coping to clipboard through angular/cdk/clipboard doesn't work. It works fine using navigator.clipboard.writeText(). 

### Reproduction

StackBlitz link: https://stackblitz.com/edit/zffwu2?file=src%2Fexample%2Fcdk-clipboard-overview-example.ts

Issues.Title: feat(MatDialog): Implement hide/show methods
Issues.Body:
### Feature Description

This feature was previously discussed on #5162.

The proposed solution was to use the addPanelClass method to hide the dialog. But it doesn't work if you are using a backdrop. I built a [demo](https://stackblitz.com/edit/hide-md-dialog-with-backdrop?file=src%2Ftest%2Ftest.component.ts) to show the problem ([TestDialog01Component](https://stackblitz.com/edit/hide-md-dialog-with-backdrop?file=src%2Ftest-dialog-01%2Ftest-dialog-01.component.ts)).  There is no way to get the current overlay of the dialog to dispose of it manually  (See #15840).

I could find a workaround ([TestDialog02Component](https://stackblitz.com/edit/hide-md-dialog-with-backdrop?file=src%2Ftest-dialog-02%2Ftest-dialog-02.component.ts)) by not using the built-in backdrop and creating a custom overlay. But it feels too hacky.

The MdDIalog should have a built-in hide/show method or expose the overlayRef. 

If the team accepts it, I could implement it and send a PR.

### Use Case

I think in at least two use cases:

- An expensive operation to render the dialog.
- Using [Optimistic UI](https://uxplanet.org/optimistic-1000-34d9eefe4c05) to hide the modal as soon as the user clicks the button, but it needs to run some async operations that depend on each other, so you cannot destroy the modal until all the operations are complete (my use case).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "feat(MatDialog): Implement hide/show methods" (#27448)

Issues.Title: bug(Slider): Rounded thumb label text value, inconsistent with actual value
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [X] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

14.2.7

### Description

Rounded thumb label text value, inconsistent with actual value.

### Reproduction

StackBlitz link: Not needed. Can be reproduced on the Material demo page for Slider.
Steps to reproduce:
1. Go to: https://v15.material.angular.io/components/slider/examples#slider-configurable (can also be reproduced on v16.1.4)
2. Enable the "Show thumb label" checkbox
3. Write the value: 12.5
4. Write the step size value: 1
There's already an inconsistency, the value stored is 12.5 but the thumb label says 13.
![image](https://github.com/angular/components/assets/17402311/2db14fdb-e506-479f-9229-23a1eb8679b6)

5. Write the step size value: 0.5
The thumb label is still rounded. 
![image](https://github.com/angular/components/assets/17402311/daf5dc90-b861-42cd-88d2-3a53322b5689)




### Expected Behavior

For the value 12.5 with the step value 0.5, I expect the thumb label to be 12.5.

When changing the step size, I expect that the thumb label is also updated accordingly.
The thumb label updates accordingly only after changing the slider value.

### Actual Behavior

For the value 12.5 with the step value 0.5, the thumb label shows the value 13.

Changing the step size doesn't update the thumb label text accordingly.



### Environment

- Angular: 15.2.9
- CDK/Material: 15.2.9
- Browser(s): Tested with Chrome, but I think all of them
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "bug(Slider): Rounded thumb label text value, inconsistent with actual value" (#27445)

Issues.Title: feat(MatStepper): Ability to focus the current step header
Issues.Body:
### Feature Description

I would like to be able to programmatically set focus to the current step header.

### Use Case

There are 2 use cases where I would like to be able to programmatically set focus to a step header:

1. When initially loading a page, I want to be able to give focus to the current step header.
2. When switching between steps programmatically using `MatStepper.next`, if anything has been done that caused the focus to shift outside of the stepper, the intended behavior of focusing the newly-selected header does not happen. I need to be able to move the focus back to the current step header.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "feat(MatStepper): Ability to focus the current step header" (#27450)

Issues.Title: build: improve dev app appearance toggles
Issues.Body:
Currently we have some toggles to change the appearance of the dev app (e.g. changing the theme, updating the direction). It has a few problems:
1. We have a lot of toggles so we're starting to run out of space in the toolbar.
2. The state of some of the toggles is saved in `localStorage` while for others it isn't.
3. The code is a bit messy since we were adding these toggles ad-hoc.

These changes address the issues by:
1. Switching all the buttons to icons which take up less space.
2. Having a centralized way to save the state to `localStorage` so we don't need to do it on a case-by-case basis.
3. Cleaning up the logic a bit.

I've also added a dedicated button for toggling the tokens theming API, because currently it's done through a query parameter which isn't easy to discover.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "build: improve dev app appearance toggles" (#27446)

Issues.Title: docs-bug(Guide): Define a typography level
Issues.Body:
### Documentation Feedback

The documentation states that I can customize the font size via:

```
@use '@angular/material' as mat;

$my-custom-level: mat.define-typography-level(
  $font-family: Roboto,
  $font-weight: 400,
  $font-size: 1rem,
  $line-height: 1,
  $letter-spacing: normal,
);
```

How can I actually make use of `$my-custom-level`? It seems that this part is missing in the documentation.

### Affected documentation page

https://material.angular.io/guide/typography#define-a-level
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "docs-bug(Guide): Define a typography level" (#27449)

Issues.Title: bug(MatTab): matieral tab header: pagination controls flickering
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [X] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

15

### Description

At some particular widths, the tab header will jump between two states:
- display the tab headers with pagination control (ie < on far left and > on far right)
- display the tab headers without pagination controls

I cannot make a sample code to show this, but it has already appeared on two of my pages. When it happens, the page width is wide enough to show all the tab headers without scrolling. Yet, the <> appears (making the headers to be displayed with less spacing) and then disappears. It is happening at more times per second than my eye can catch. All I can see is a pair of blur images for each tab header, since they are placed at slightly different locations with vs without the <>. On inspection, the class `mat-mdc-tab-header-pagination-controls-enabled` will be applied and removed from the mat-tab-header at top speed.

This is the same as the [locked issue 27084](https://github.com/angular/components/issues/27084)

@amysorto 

### Reproduction

I have no idea how to reproduce it, it happens when the material tab group has a particular range of width.

Even given a page with a material tab group, it is not always possible to resize the page to make this happen.

[Refer to the photo I took](https://photos.app.goo.gl/n8BDCaRZsSqsaLjJ6)



### Expected Behavior

the tab headers should either be displayed with or without the scrolling controls < and >

### Actual Behavior

the display is swapping between the two, making the headers unreadable.

### Environment

- Angular: 16.1.4
- CDK/Material: 16.1.4
- Browser(s): Chrome Version 114.0.5735.199 (Official Build) (64-bit)
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows 10 21H2
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(MatTab): matieral tab header: pagination controls flickering" (#27443)

Issues.Title: Angular Material DatePicker: Allow option to show two months in the date picker
Issues.Body:
### Feature Description

This feature was requested 5 years ago so I figured it would be worth asking if circumstances have changed to be able to have the option to show two months in the date picker as requested earlier in this issue [Git Hub Issue 14586](https://github.com/angular/components/issues/14586).

![image](https://github.com/angular/components/assets/113653924/440ce3c4-2ad6-4a76-8664-c25115da8ccb)

I think the original requestor has provided a pretty decent description of the feature.

A couple of suggestions would be

a) It would be available both in single date picker and date range picker.
b) It would be an opt-in setting, which by default would be off so it's backward compatible.
 ` <mat-datepicker [multimonth]="true #picker></mat-datepicker>`
   
and

`<mat-date-range-picker [multimonth]="true #picker #picker></mat-date-range-picker>`


But if feedback is needed I'd be happy to provide more details.


### Use Case

Most users now prefer a two month date picker which there are other options to choose from, but we've invested into the material components so it'd be nice if this was available natively.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Angular Material DatePicker: Allow option to show two months in the date picker" (#27441)

Issues.Title: bug(MatAutocompleteModule): Unable to navigate between autocomplete input and overlay options panel using iOS VoiceOver
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

Using IOS VoiceOver, using gesture to cycle between form controls, skips the overlay panel and thus preventing user from selecting a valid option.

The issue can be reproduced using  [Autocomplete example from Material components page ](https://material.angular.io/components/autocomplete/examples)


 



### Reproduction

StackBlitz link: https://stackblitz.com/edit/pqfm6j
Steps to reproduce:
1. Access the page using IOS device (iPhone)
2. Enable VoiceOver 
3. Using gesture swipe navigate to the autoccomplete field
4. `double tap` to edit "number" field
5.  Swipe to search for letter "O" (as in Oscar)
6. `double tap` to accept selection "O"
7. Now two options are displayed on screen "One" , "Two"
8. use `Swipe Right` gesture to cycle between values


### Expected Behavior

Expected behaviour is, when dropdown with selectable values appear, user should be able to cycle through options using swipe gesture 

### Actual Behavior

Actual Behaviour is :
The focus skips the available options displayed and focuses on next form field, leaving the Autocomplete field

### Environment

- Angular:  16.1.1
- CDK/Material: 16.1.4
- Browser(s): Safari, Google Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): iOS 15, iOS16
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(MatAutocompleteModule): Unable to navigate between autocomplete input and overlay options panel using iOS VoiceOver  " (#27442)

Issues.Title: fix(material/expansion): panel content visible when placed inside a hidden parent
Issues.Body:
The expansion panel was setting `visibility: visible` on the content which meant that it would be visible when placed inside of a parent that is `visibility: hidden`.

These changes resolve the issue by clear the `visibility` instead.

Fixes #27436.
